November 2018

Indicators and Innovative Mechanisms for 
Guangdong Province

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the development of 
industry  green  growth  indicators  and  innovative  mechanisms  through  research,  capacity 
development, and policy advice to promote the green growth of the industries in Guangdong 
Province in the People’s Republic of China (PRC).1 
 
2.  The Government of the PRC has requested TA from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
as part of its efforts to establish a comprehensive indicator and evaluation framework, system, 
and implementation mechanism to (i) improve the environmental performance of industries in 
Guangdong, and (ii) support decision-making for future potential green financing. Following a 
mission on 21–22 May 2018, ADB and the government reached an understanding on the TA 
objectives, scope, implementation arrangements, costs, and terms of reference for consultants.2 
The TA is included in ADB’s country operations business plan, 2018–2020 for the PRC.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Since the PRC commenced economic reforms in 1978 and its open door policy in 1979, 
Guangdong  has  rapidly  developed  from  a  lagging  agricultural  area  into  the  country’s  key 
manufacturing base. As of 2016, Guangdong was the most populous region in the country and 
ranked first among the PRC regions in gross regional product, accounting for 11% of the PRC’s 
gross domestic product.4 By economic sector, its gross regional product ratios in 2016 were 
4.6 (primary), 43.4 (secondary), and 52.0 (tertiary). About 79% of Guangdong’s gross regional 
product is concentrated in the Pearl River Delta, which creates regional disparity within the 
province.5 
 
4.  Environmental degradation is a serious issue for the PRC. Guangdong, which took a lead 
role at the time of the economic opening, also took a very active role in remedying environmental 
issues. As guided by the central government, Guangdong established policies to achieve an 
environmentally friendly society and promote green growth.6 However, it still relies heavily on a 
high-input, high-consumption, and high-emission development model. Industries consume more 
than 60% of the total energy in Guangdong. Small and medium-sized enterprises support its 
manufacturing industry, but most of them are in the lower hierarchy of industrial supply chains 
that still largely depend on traditional labor, energy, and resource-intensive production methods. 
The provincial government agencies issued various policies and measures to promote the green 
growth of industries but they are fragmented and do not provide practical guidance for enterprises, 
industrial parks, or cities on how to adopt and implement environmental improvement measures. 
                                                
1  According to the classification used in the China Statistical Yearbook, the secondary economic sector includes 
gongye (industries) and construction. Gongye covers (i) mining; (ii) manufacturing; and (iii) production and supply of 
electricity, heat, gas, and water. In this paper, “industry” and “industries” refer to “gongye.” 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 October 2018. 
3  ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2018–2020. Manila.  
4   Guangdong had 109.99 million people in 2016, accounting for 8% of the country’s population. Guangdong’s gross 
regional product was CNY8.085 trillion in 2016. Its per capita gross regional product is ranked seventh in the PRC 
after Beijing, Fujian, Jiangsu, Shanghai, Tianjin, and Zhejiang provinces and cities. National Bureau of Statistics of 
China. 2017. China Statistical Yearbook 2017. Beijing: China Statistics Press. 
5   Guangdong Province consists of 21 prefecture-level cities. The Pearl River Delta consists of nine prefecture-level 
cities: Dongguan, Foshan, Guangzhou, Huizhou, Jiangmen, Shenzhen, Zhaoqing, Zhongshan, and Zhuhai. Statistics 
Bureau of Guangdong Province. 2017. Guangdong Statistical Yearbook 2017. Beijing: China Statistics Press. 
6  For example: People’s Government of Guangdong Province. 2016. Guangdong Provincial Ecological Civilization 
Construction Thirteenth Five-Year Plan. Guangzhou; and Guangdong Economic and Information Commission. 2016. 
Guangdong Province Industry Green Development Implementation Scheme. Guangzhou.

2 
5.  To solve the problem of fragmented policy guidance and the difficulty of putting it into 
practice, the TA team will conduct research on a usable indicator system to evaluate green growth 
opportunities  for  enterprises,  industrial  parks,  and  cities;  and  propose  innovative  ways  for 
Guangdong to promote green growth, such as an evaluation and assessment mechanism, green 
financing mechanisms, and selection criteria, which will complement an ongoing ADB study.7 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impacts:  the  energy  consumption  per  unit  of 
Guangdong’s major manufacturing products reduced; and the circular economy of more than 
100 economic  parks  in  the  province  improved.8 The  TA  will  have  the  following  outcome: 
comprehensive indicator and evaluation framework on green growth in Guangdong established.9 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
7.  Output 1: Good practices and lessons on industry green growth and evaluation 
system studied and documented. The TA team will support the executing and implementing 
agencies and key policy makers to deepen the understanding of green growth evaluation by the 
following: 
(i)  reviewing existing industry green growth indicators and identify issues and areas 
for improvement; 
(ii)  conducting field surveys, on-site visits, and interviews to document the status of 
enterprises, industrial parks, and the cities’ industry green growth in Guangdong; 
(iii)  organizing overseas study visits to learn from experience in 
(a)  green growth planning, establishment of a circular industry system, and 
development of an evaluation system; 
(b)  industry transformation and upgrades, innovative policies on green finance 
and credit, and policy coordination; and 
(c)  energy  conservation,  environmental  protection,  clean  production;  and 
policies, measures, and actions to incentivize take-up by enterprises; 
(iv)  conducting study visits to regions and cities in the PRC where green industrial and 
urban development is being implemented, to learn from their experiences; and  
(v)  draft the Guangdong Industry Green Growth Catalogue. 
 
8.  Output 2: Indicators to comprehensively evaluate Guangdong industries’ green 
growth developed. Based on the research and lessons, the TA will support the following: 
                                                
7  The term “industry green growth” in this TA refers to environmental performance improvement of industries and 
indicators, and indicators will be designed to meet the needs of benchmarking Guangdong’s unique environmental 
challenges. While the indicator envisaged in this TA solely focuses on the green growth aspect, the underlying idea 
is consistent with the existing efforts such as the Inclusive Green Growth Index that ADB is developing as a new 
benchmark to measure countries’ well-being by considering broad aspects of development. These are (i) economic 
growth,  (ii)  social  equity,  and  (iii)  environmental  sustainability.  S.  Jha.  2018.  Measuring,  Monitoring,  and 
Operationalizing Quality of Growth–Implications for the People’s Republic of China. ADB Briefs. No. 98. Manila: ADB. 
8   People’s Government of Guangdong Province. 2016. Guangdong Provincial Ecological Civilization Construction 
Thirteenth Five-Year Plan. Guangzhou. The plan’s targets are (i) Guangdong’s major manufacturing products’ energy 
consumption per unit is reduced to the leading level in the country, (ii) the rate of comprehensive utilization of 
industrial solid waste exceeds 85%, (iii) more than 100 economic parks in the provinces improved to circular 
economy, and (iv) about 10,000 enterprises complete clean production audit.  
9   The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
(i)  preparation  of  industry  green  growth  evaluation  indicators  for  Guangdong, 
including the proposal for applying high-level technologies in collecting, monitoring, 
and evaluation of the indicators; 
(ii)  evaluation of pilot enterprises, industrial parks, and cities using the proposed 
indicator and evaluation method; and 
(iii)  preparation of a report on an innovative green growth for Guangdong’s industries 
and on innovative mechanisms to evaluate and monitor the indicators. 
The report will discuss new method that integrate policies on different perspectives of green 
growth, such as energy saving and emission reduction, industrial technological retrofits, and 
financial support tools. The proposed evaluation system and the new mechanisms will be 
applicable to all areas in Guangdong. 
 
9.  Output 3: Financial system and mechanism to promote green development and 
design of innovative financing projects prepared. The TA will support the preparation of the 
following: 
(i)  a research report with practical recommendations for innovative public green 
financing processes that are compatible with Guangdong’s local situation, e.g., the 
provincial  transfer  payment  system,  ecological  subsidies,  and  other  financial 
support tools;  
(ii)  a design proposal for green financing projects that meet local needs; and 
(iii)   a list of green financing projects suitable for potential funding support from ADB 
and other foreign financial institutions to promote industry green growth. 
 
10.  TA consultants’ team will develop the indicators and mechanisms in consultation with the 
Guangdong Economic and Information Commission (GDEI) and Guangdong Provincial Finance 
Department.  The  pilot  evaluation  exercise  will  rate  the  green  performance  of  enterprises, 
industrial parks, and cities for internal references. The GDEI will adopt the research outcomes 
and recommendations as standardized tools and mechanisms and apply them to activities such 
as  comprehensive  utilization  of  industrial  solid  waste,  assessment  of  energy  conservation, 
planning of pollution prevention and control, development of a resource recycling base, and 
funding support for the industries’ energy conservation and environmental protection efforts. The 
executing agencies will submit the policy proposals to the provincial government for inclusion in 
its Fourteenth Five-Year Plan. Toward the end of the TA, ADB and the executing agencies will 
decide on how to disseminate the final reports as knowledge products, either in summary or in 
full, in English or in Chinese. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $350,000, of which $300,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are  listed  in  Appendix  2.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of 
counterpart staff, meeting facilities, data, information, printing, coordination and arrangement 
activities, part of interpretation cost, domestic study visits, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA and will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants during the 
implementation of the TA. GDEI and Guangdong Provincial Finance Department will be the joint 
executing agencies responsible for providing guidance and support to stakeholders during the 
implementation. Guangdong Energy Conservation Center, a subsidiary agency of GDEI, will be

4 
the implementing agency responsible for working closely with the consultants engaged under the 
TA and coordinating between stakeholders during the implementation. 
 
13.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements

and the associated project administration instructions and/or TA staff instructions. 
Source: ADB. 
 
14.  Consulting services. ADB will engage 15.5 person-months of consulting services—three 
international consultants for a total of 6.0 person-months, and three national consultants for a total 
of 9.5 person-months through individual consultant selection following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated project administration instructions 
and/or TA staff instructions.10 ADB will recruit individual consultants because of the need for 
specialized and country-specific expertise. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to the 
People’s Republic of China for Industry Green Growth Indicators and Innovative Mechanisms for 
Guangdong Province, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                
10  Terms of reference for consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Good practices and lessons on industry green growth and evaluation system studied and 
documented 
1.1 Conduct field surveys in Q1–Q2 2019 
1.2 Conduct international study visits in Q1–Q3 2019 
1.3 Conduct domestic study visits in Q1–Q3 2019 
1.4 Draft the Guangdong Industry Green Growth Catalogue in Q2 2019–Q1 2020 
 
2.  Indicators to comprehensively evaluate Guangdong industries’ green growth developed 
2.1 Conduct TA inception meeting to discuss the research objectives and direction in Q1 2019 
2.2 Conduct TA workshop to discuss the research progress in Q2–Q3 2019 
2.3 Prepare green indicators and pilot evaluation, and draft a research report in Q1 2019–Q1 2020 
2.4 Conduct TA workshop with external peer reviewers in Q4 2019–Q1 2020 
2.5 Submit the research recommendations to the provincial government as input for the Fourteenth Five-
Year Plan by April 2020 
2.6 Conduct TA final workshop for dissemination in Q2 2020 
 
3.  Financial system and mechanism to promote green development and design of innovative 
financing projects prepared 
3.1 Draft research report on green financing mechanisms in Q1 2019–Q1 2020 
3.2 Prepare a long list of green financing projects for ADB and other financial institutions by Q1 2020 
3.3 Propose potential green finance projects for ADB’s programming discussion by Q1 2020
